dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge printing PRESSES POUND out the morning edition, setting a rhythm that carries us through the scene as the newspapers are printed, collated, folded, and spit out onto a rapidly-growing stack. Pressmen bundle the papers and toss them into carts. the masthead: "THE NEW YORK WORLD, JULY 10, 1899." Two men push hard a cart loaded with papers to get it rolling down an iron ramp -- then have to run to keep up with it as it careens toward --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broad-necked workmen grab the carts and begin unloading them -- stacks of paper grow as the POUNDING RHYTHM BUILD and we GO TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man's feet move up some stairs (in rhythm) -- they belong to KLOPPMAN, 70s, who enters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large room filled with boys sleeping in hammocks, including JACK KELLY, snapping his fingers in his sleep. On the wall by his head, the commanding visage of Teddy Roosevelt grins down from a rotogravure photo. Kloppman wakes the boys, intoning his morning ritual:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ink's wet, the presses are rolling, the papers are stacking -- rise and shine, make a dime, no news without the Newsies -- etc. Jack jumps out of his bunk and shakes the BOY below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, Crutchy -- The World is waitin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yawning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Mr. Pulitzer my yacht was lost at sea. Jack laughs and tosses him his crutch. The dorm is now alive with waking boys -- yawning, stretching, pulling on pants, hitching up suspenders as they sing -- SONG: "CARRYIN' THE BANNER" (Approx. 7 minutes, 15 seconds)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys begin to wake,                          KID BLIN yawning, stretching,                HEY BUMMERS, WE GOT W complaining as they hit the floor: pants pulled                         SPECS on, suspenders hitched             SINCE WHEN DID YOU BEC up, boots laced tight.               MY MUDDER?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSH, cross-eyed and skinny with big ears and lisp, play- fully pushes the NEWSIE so he falls on his hammock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, whattaya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Younger boys pump water for       older boys, then trade Teeth brushing, sponge baths       with cold water -- the boys shave. Jack smears his        face with shaving crea Mush pulls up a box next to       him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you sleep, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On me back, Mush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks that's hilarious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear that, you hear what he said? I ast how'd he sleep --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, this look like I'm fakin' it? He hobbles towards Jack on one crutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says you're fakin' it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are fulla fakes these days -- it's hurtin' the rep of genuine articles like myself. I gotta find me a new sellin' spot, where they ain't used to seein' me. Jack smiles; Mush taps Crutchy on the arm... sings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack rinses his face, takes                  SKITTERY special care adjusting his      THEY ALMOST ALL KNOWS HOW red bandana.                      READ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and the Newsies coming                    CHORUS down the stairs, greeting         A MIGHTY FINE LIFE Kloppman and moving out the       CARRYING THE BANNER door --                           TOUGH 'N' TALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands next to Crutchy                    CHORUS and Mush as the boys file         CARRYING THE BANNER out.                              HOME-FREE ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at the morning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your leg say, Crutch? Feel like rain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feels his leg; shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No rain -- partly cloudy, clearin' towards evenin'. (as Jack laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who ya sellin' wit, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't decided yet. Jack spots a passing wagon and helps Crutchy on board -- he and Mush jump on for the ride and they all move off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID JACOBS, 15, hurries down the street as his brother, LES, 8, dawdles after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, hurry up, willya? Why do I gotta be saddled with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I gotta be saddled with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- They'll run out of papers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KID BLINK, 16, one eye covered by a patch, moves past a fruit stand with three of his boys. He's about to swipe a banana when the shadow of a cop on horseback looms over him. Blink smiles up at the COP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Mornin', Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm keepin' my eye on you, Blink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll keep my eye on you, too, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get moving! Blink and the boys race into an alley --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy's hand shoots some dice -- it belongs to RACETRACK HIGGINS, an Italian beanpole, who's gambling with THREE OTHER BOYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Race picks up his               THAT MAKES IT TEN GAMES O winnings and admires              OF TEN the pile of change in his hand.                                    RACETRACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wiped out -- my mother'll murder me -- if I had one. The wagon passes -- Jack, Mush and Crutchy get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack -- whattaya know, whattaya say. Got a hot tip on a nag in the fourth at Sheepshead -- sure t'ing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your last sure t'ing's still runnin', Racetrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the world's best audience) Ya hear that? Race says sure t'ing                    * and Jack says -- ya hear what he                      * said, ya hear it, he said --                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (together)                                     * We heard it!                                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David still hurrying -- Les slows to hop on a hopscotch game chalked on the sidewalk. David grabs his hand and pulls him on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid Blink and his boys come out of an alley, joining Jack and the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Cowboy -- I hear Medda's breakin' in a new act at the vaudeville tonight -- ya interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That an echo? Or is the Crip followin' ya again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swinging his crutch) Yeah? How'd you like it if a crip cracked your head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better choke it, Blink -- 'fore you need another patch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, who ya sellin' wit, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not wit you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing personal, Blink, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack sings, the boys             RESIST listen carefully. They all respect his opinion.                       RACETRACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and the others                            ALL BOYS round a corner                    SUMMER STINKS AND WINTE singing as they move                WAITIN' through an alley filled           WELCOME TO NEW YAWK with barrels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the square                        ALL singing.                        BOY, AIN'T NATURE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move towards a             STILL IT'S A FINE LIFE breakfast wagon run by          CARRYIN' THE BANNER three NUNS.                       WITH ME CHUMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the breakfast wagon,                      CRUTCHY the boys line up for            I'M NO SNOOZER coffee -- Blink tries to        SITTIN' MAKES ME ANTSY butt in front of Jack,          I LIKES LIVIN' CHANCEY who spins him back to Race, who spins him further back                   ALL as Crutchy and Mush jump        HARLEM TO DELANCEY in and Blink ends up            WHAT A FINE LIFE last. BOOTS ARBUS, 15,          CARRYING THE BANNER black, joins the line.          THROUGH THE SLUMS -- ONE NUN ladles coffee from                   NUNS a large pot into the boys'      BLESSED CHILDREN cups; the OTHER NUN hands       THOUGH YOU WANDER LOST them each a roll.                 AND DEPRAVED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout savin' me another roll -- okay, sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoves him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!     Save some for the rest of us! The Nun smiles and gives them both one.

dialogues.speaker: SEARCHING MOTHER
dialogues.text: is singing as she looks for her lost son in the crowd around the wagon. Jack and the others sing in counter- point as she passes by.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MOTHER                         RACETRACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal                         ALL entire square as Jack and      IF I HATE THE HEADLINE the gang leave the wagon,      I'LL MAKE UP A HEADLINE cross the square and head      AND I'LL SAY ANYTHING I HA for the gates of The World     'CAUSE AT TWO FOR A PENNY Building, keeping their        IF I TAKE TOO MANY eyes on the huge blackboards   WEASEL JUST MAKES ME EAT ' over the street.                 AFTA Newsies of all   ages and sizes appear from every conceiv able space and   line up outside the gates, waiting for them to open,   anxiously praying for a good headline to chalked on the   boards overhead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men climb ladders to the blackboards above the street and start to write out headlines in chalk: "TROLLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP of NEWSIES follow through an alley that leads them to the square, where they see the men chalking up headlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP OF NEWSIES cross the street and split up around the statue as they walk into the square --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and the gang join                     ALL Newsies as they               WE NEED A GOOD ASSASSINATIO converge outside The World gates, singing and yelling    WE NEED AN EARTHQUAKE OR A at the men on the chalkboard.   WAR One newsie yells out:                      SNIPESHOOTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mush jumps all over him:                   ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies sing at each other:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies line up outside the gate, singing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MORE)                       (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: NEAR GATES
dialogues.text: Suddenly the music becomes a quiet pulse as the DELANCEY BROTHERS -- OSCAR and MORRIS, two muscle-bound goons -- push with deliberate aggression past Jack and the boys. Tension, silence, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffs the air) Dear me. What is dat unpleasant aroma? I fear de sewer has backed up during de night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too rotten to be the sewer.   It must be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the Delancey brothers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For revenge, Oscar jerks Snipeshooter out of line and propels him to the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inna back, ya ugly little shrimp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar and Morris glare at the crowd, daring anyone to do anything about it. Jack calmly walks Snipe back to his place in line, then faces the Delanceys who try to stare him down. The air is electric. Nearby --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five to one, I say Cowboy skunks 'em -- who's bettin', who's bettin' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies shake their heads.    Nearby the staring contest continues until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be callin' people ugly little shrimps. Oscar. Unless you're referrin; to the family resemblance in your brother here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers glower, look at each other, then back at Jack, who grins at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. It's an insult. And so's this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack deftly reaches out both hands and flips the derbys off both their heads. The brothers scramble for them and the chase is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANCE BREAK... The Delanceys chase Jack throughout the square, entertaining the Newsies... a morning tradition. The Newsies sing in counterpoint, underscoring the chase.

dialogues.speaker: HORACE GREELY STATUE
dialogues.text: are just arriving, hurrying towards the gates on a collision course with -- Jack who comes barrelling around the statue and runs smack into David. For a moment, everything stops -- Jack catches his breath, David looks at him in outrage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it, willya? What do you think you're doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathing hard) Runnin'.

dialogues.speaker: 19A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He speeds on -- just as the Delanceys come thundering around the statue, bowling David to the pavement. Les looks at Jack as if he's watching Robin Hood and Br'er Rabbit rolled into one.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR GATES
dialogues.text: keeps running, keeping just out of the Delanceys' grasp -- but then he trips and they've got him. Morris lifts him high into the air to smash him onto the cobblestones. The crowd stops breathing -- but then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack grabs the bars and like a monkey jerks free of the bully's grasp. The kids howl, loving the show as Jack avoids the brothers moving from bar to bar like Tarzan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NUMBER ENDS (APPROXIMATE TIME: 7:15) and the moment is broken when a BELL inside the World Building RINGS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comin' down de chute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Delancey brothers, reluctantly, give up the chase, and back towards the entrance to the World gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't finished with you yet, Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gatekeeper unlocks and swings open the huge gates. Jack hangs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ride 'em, cowboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newsies yell out Jack's name as he rides the gates 'til the last possible moment, then leaps into the back of a wagon. Jack takes a bow as the boys cheer, moving into line. Les watches Jack, his new hero, as David pulls him along. 4/8/91 YELLOW                                         15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newsies jostle for position at the window -- David shoving and jostling like the rest. He manages to elbow in near the front. Les, hanging back, has his eyes on -- -- Jack sauntering coolly to his natural place at the head of the line, flanked by Boots and Mush. He leans on the counter and grins at the rodent-faced man inside the window: WEASEL, 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya miss me, Weasel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my name -- it's Weisel. Mister Weisel to you. How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't rush me -- I'm perusin'                          * the mercandice... Mr. Weasel.                          * The Newsies love it as Jack deliberately takes a paper, turns and scans.  Seeing Les staring at him, Jack winks. Les smiles back, fascinated. Jack turns back to Weasel with a fifty-cent piece. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual. Weasel grabs for the coin -- Jack flips it out of his grasp and onto the counter. The Newsies whoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred for the wiseguy -- next!                       * Oscar slams the papers down and Jack gives them a quick flip-count -- eyes closed -- as he moves away. Behind him, Race and the others get their papers.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: scans the newspaper for a catchy headline; Race, Crutchy, the others wander up, doing the same. A commotion O.S. and they look up to see -- -- at the window, Weasel is in David's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya got ya papes -- move outta here.                    *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paid for twenty -- you only gave                     * me nineteen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loving it) You callin' me a liar, kid...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's sweating, aware that all eyes are on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that other paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Delanceys start for David when suddenly Jack steps up, slams his hand on David's papers, closes his eyes and does a flip-count. The expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen, Weasel. An honest mistake -- on account of Oscar can't count to twenty with his shoes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weasel glowers -- but wants to get back to business. backhands Morris who looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it.   Race -- spot me two-bits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Race flips him a coin.     Jack slaps it on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another fifty for my friend here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want another fifty -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving away) Sure you do. Every newsie wants more papes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, puzzled, grabs the papers and he and Les run after Jack --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack moves on as David and Les hurry after him.      The trails along, watching, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These papers are yours, I don't take charity from nobody! I don't even know who you are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowboy!   They call him Cowboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns, grins at Les.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That and a lotta other things -- including Jack Kelly, which is what my mudder called me. What do they call you, kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled) Les. This is David, he's my brother. He's older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely glances at David) No kiddin'. How old are you, Les?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No good. Anybody asks, you're seven. (as Les is appalled) Younger sells more papes, Les -- and if we're gonna be partners --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it! Who said anything about partners -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe me two bits, right? Okay, so I consider it an investment. We sell together, split 70-30, plus you get the benefit of observin' me -- no charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David) You're gettin' the chance of a lifetime here -- you learn from Jack, you learn from the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's the best, then why does he need us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need you, pal. But I ain't                     * got a cute little brother to front                     * for me. And Les here...                                * (smiles down at Les who smiles back up angelically) ... With this kid's puss and my God-given talent, we can easy move a thousand papers a week. Whattaya say? Deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is incredulous, but Les is pleading.      David sig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta split fifty-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-forty.   Or I forget the whole t'ing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David reluctantly offers his hand. Jack spits in his palm and shakes. Les whoops and they move off, Jack already being the mentor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name of the game is volume, Dave. You only took twenty papes -- why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad headline...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First t'ing you gotta learn -- headlines don't sell papes, newsies sell papes. We're what holds this town together -- without newsies, nobody knows nuttin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move away from Newsie Square as above them, the GOLDEN DOME OF THE WORLD BUILDING glistens in the morning sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very large magnifying glass in in the hands of someone O.S. -- it moves across the front page of today's World as we hear the headline being read by --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading sarcastically) 'Trolley Strike Drags On for Third Week' -- this so-called headline drags on for infinity!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A hand smashes the paper onto an ornate desk beyond which cower three harried employees of The World, including SEITZ, 45, the hard-bitten business manager. BUNSEN, the editor, and JONATHAN, an accountant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news is slow, Chief, the Trolley Strike's all we got --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all Mr. William Randolph Hearst has, too -- see how he covers the strike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The magnifying glass swings to a copy of the New York Journal with a large black headline: "NUDE CORPSE ON RAILS -- NOT CONNECTED TO TROLLEY STRIKE." The CAMERA COMES AROUND to reveal JOSEPH PULITZER, himself, a thundering presence in smoked-glasses and a beard, wielding the magnifying glass like a gavel of judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearst is killing us in the circulation war -- and you give me headlines that would put a whirling dervish to sleep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous editor) We'll get a new headline writer, Mr. Pulitzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steal Hearst's man -- offer him double what Hearst pays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how he stole him from us. (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, you spend as much as you make fighting Hearst. That's why the paper's losing money --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I created the World to be the best and I'll spend whatever it takes to -- (stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that deafening noise? It's the Newsies far below, barely audible to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the Newsies, Chief, I'll --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind -- where was I?                             *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creating the World, Chief.                             *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This paper's losing money because there's too much fat, inefficiency -- not because I'm fighting to                         * make us number one! Well, we're going to cut costs, maximize profits -- and still beat the socks off Hearst -- (beat) I want to know how by tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDERSCORED: Jack leads David and Les through an open- air market crowded with carts and people -- all the sights and sounds and smells of the melting pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some newsies got corners, see -- same spot, same customers. Me,                         * I like to keep moving, enjoy the life of the big city. I spot an opportunity, I sell a pape. That's the advantage of being an independent businessman, instead                       * of workin' for wages.                                  *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sees TWO LOVERS kissing on the steps of a building -- he tries his luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paper, mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without breaking the kiss, the man kicks out at David who jumps away. Shaking his head, Jack whispers something to Les, who rushes over to the Lovers, still kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earsplitting shout) Extry -- 'Runaway Carriage Crushes Cop!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lovers spring apart -- the man looks like he's going to throttle Les, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cooing) Oh, honey... look at that sweet little lamb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, watching with Jack, can't believe this.       Les running back waving a coin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gimme a dime! He said I should go far away and keep the change!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack takes the dime; Les's face falls.     He flips it ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a natural, kid. You remind me of me -- and I can't say greater than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: duke it out as sidewalk spectators watch.      The boys w the crowd, each in his own style --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the rookie) Extra, 'Trolley strike drags on!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the master) Nextry, nextry -- 'Ellis Island in flames -- big con-fla-gration!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- ?   Where's that story -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making sales) Page nine -- thank you, sir. Nextry, 'Thousands flee in panic -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on page nine) 'Trash fire near immigration building frightens seagulls -- ?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Terrified flight from flaming inferno!' Thank you, much obliged --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: David is incredulous -- then sees Les by the boxers moving up to a spectator, assuming a pathetic look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy me last pape, mista...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He coughs, Camille-like. Makes the sale. Down the sidewalk Jack nods approvingly; David is disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our father taught us not to lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine taught me not to starve. So we both got an education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just make things up -- like those headlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do nothin' the guys who write this stuff don't do. It ain't lyin' -- it's just improvin' the truth a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les comes running back, wiping his mouth, with a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy gave me a quarter! Quick, gimme some more last papers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs him) Hold it -- I smell beer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy bet me I wouldn't drink some -- that's how I made the quarter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, no drinkin' on the job -- it's bad for business. What if somebody called a cop or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les' eyes go wide as he sees -- behind Jack -- a burly Irish cop (MacSWAIN) hurrying up with a cadaverous vul- ture of a man, SNYDER, who's pointing straight at them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is, officer -- do your duty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack spins, sees the man --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat it -- the bulls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He races off. David, confused, races after him, Les looks very worried as he runs with David --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for one little sip of beer -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder and MacSwain in pursuit as Jack leads them into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys pound down the alley, Snyder and MacSwain round the corner behind them, Snyder shouting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Sullivan! Stop, I say!     You hear me, Sullivan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Sullivan -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mistaken identity -- all micks look alike to these birds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still worried) One sip! I didn't even swallow it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack leads them into the doorway of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clatter up flights of stairs -- Snyder and MacSwain clattering up below them, shouting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You young miscreant! Wait'll I get you back to the Refuge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Refuge -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaps over a Sleeping Man on the stairwell; so do David and Les as they run out onto --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More sleepers; people living in makeshift shelters. Jack runs to a plank stretched between two buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not crossing that! Anyway, I don't think they're chasing us --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack scoops up Les -- who's loving it -- and carries him across the plank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?   What're they doin' then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're chasing you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder and MacSwain huff out onto the roof. David, still uncertain, looks back at them -- the runs across the plank. Jack calmly topples the plank to the street as the pursuers reach it, gasping for breath -- he gives Snyder a little salute, then moves on to a rooftop exit -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys run out of a doorway onto the street; Jack stops, looks around carefully, as if expecting Snyder to come bounding out of the sky. David is bursting with suspicion -- starts to say something, but Jack shushes him, leads them quickly, furtively into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack runs to a side door and opens it, waving David and Les inside. He follows, giving a quick look around before he closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC lilting somewhere -- for a moment we don't know we're in a theater, as the boys huddle against a wall, catching their breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want some answers -- Why was he chasing you? What's the Refuge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Refuge is this jail for kids. That guy, Snyder, he's the warden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in jail...?   Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was starvin'. I stole some food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Right, food. He called you 'Sullivan' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bridling) Yeah, food. My name's Kelly, Jack Kelly, like I told you. Think I'm lyin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a way of 'improving the truth.' Why was he chasing you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I escaped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awestruck) Oh, boy. How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This big shot gimme a ride out in his carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Bet it was the mayor, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. Teddy Roosevelt.    Ever heard of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David starts to reply when he sees something behind Jack that makes his mouth drop open. At the top of a short flight of stairs, a vision is frowning down at them, speaking in a theatrical Swedish accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accent) What is the meaning of this? No one is allowed backstage -- you will leave at once! Out, out, out, out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She descends the stairs grandly, shooing them away like pigeons. Jack turns to her and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't kick me out without a kiss goodbye, wouldya, Medda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprised, she gasps in delight -- throwing her arms around Jack. David can't believe it. Medda's accent quickly disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly, where've you been, kid? I miss you up in the balcony -- you know I sing all my songs to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is David and Les. And this is the greatest star of the vaudeville stage today, Miss Medda Larkson, the Swedish Meadowlark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accent) Welcome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medda also owns the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no accent; to David) Don't ever own a theater, kid. Don't even think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awed) I won't. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing Les) What have we here -- ? Aren't you the cutest little fella that ever was -- yes, you are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into his act) Buy my last pape, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Camille-cough.     Medda looks at him critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kid is good. Speaking as one professional to another, I'd say you got a future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay if we hang here awhile, Medda? 'Til a little problem outside goes away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you like -- now the lark must warble. Hey, you -- (flags down a passing candy butcher) -- give my guests whatever they want.

dialogues.speaker: 26C CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She winks at the dazzled boys and hits the stage, singing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) 'MY LOVEY-DOVEY BABY'... etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Jack can't take their eyes off her; Les can't take his eyes off the candy butcher's tray...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les is looking green from all the candy as he follows Jack and David, balancing on trolley tracks. In the distance, the FAINT sound of SHOUTING/SINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late, my folks'll be worried ... What about yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're out west lookin' for a place for us to live -- (takes something from his pocket) -- like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the cover of a dime novel with a blue-perfect sky over a perfect yellow desert; a large red sun shines down on a perfect adobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Sante Fe -- out in New Mexico? Soon's Pop finds us the right ranch, they're sendin' for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sleepily) Then you'll be a real cowboy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack nods quietly. David looks at Jack, not believing a word of what he's saying; seeing how much he wants it to be true... The SINGING grows LOUDER, the haunting refrain of "Seize The Day," as the boys continue -- 4/8/91 YELLOW                                        28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the street, a trolley is in flames, surrounded by a mob of shouting men. David looks at it nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we divvy up at my place...? You can meet my folks... The mob is chasing two men towards them, screaming --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scabs!   Soak the scabs!   Etc. A conductor with a bloody head and terrified face runs past them -- but conductor two is caught, tackled, beaten -- David pulls Les away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack -- let's get outta here -- ! The boys move away, Jack looking back at the beating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow we get a decent headline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys enter, Jack carrying the sleeping Les.   ESTHER, 38, is setting the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing Les)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God...! What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just sleeping, Momma -- She quickly takes him from Jack. MAYER, 43, is relieved but angry to see his sons -- his right arm is bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been waiting dinner -- where've you been? David says nothing; crosses to the table and dumps the day's receipts on it, looks up at his father proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made all this selling papers...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half of it's Jack's -- he's our selling partner. And our friend. This is my parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack nods awkwardly, starts to say something when SARAH, 16, enters from another room with an armload of lace piecework. She's beautiful -- Jack becomes instantly tongue-tied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Sarah.    My sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles -- Jack still can't find his tongue.       May seeing his awkwardness, steps in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esther -- maybe David's partner would like to stay for dinner. Add some more water to the soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mortified) Mayer...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayer laughs, joined by Sarah and David -- and finally Esther herself as she waters the soup. Jack stands drinking in the family's warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les mumbles in his sleep on a board stretched between two chairs. Jack, eating heartily, his eloquence regained, holds forth at the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I saw today, I gotta say your boys are born Newsies, Mr. Jacobs. With my experience and their hard work -- just a little more, thanks -- (third bowl of soup) -- I figure we can peddle a thousand a week and not break a sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That many...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More when the headline's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes a headline good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catchy words -- like, uh, 'corpse' or 'maniac,' or, let's see, 'love nest' or 'nude' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah and David giggle; Esther looks shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) 'Scuse the language there, uh, maybe I'm talkin' too much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) You talk fine, Jack -- Sarah, get that cake your mother's been hiding in the cabinet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for your birthday tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had enough birthdays!    This is a celebration!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David leaps up to fetch silver; Sarah gets a luscious chocolate cake from a cabinet --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only the beginning -- the longer I work, the more I'll make --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work only until I go back to the factory! Then you go back to school, like you promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All activity stops, an awkward silence.       Mayer looks his bandaged hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will heal... they'll give me back my job... I'll make them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sees how worried the family is.       No one seems a to speak, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his sleep) 'Gimme all ya got, baby...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is shocked -- except for Jack and David, who sputter into laughter. The celebration is restored -- Jack digs into an enormous slab of cake, looking around at the smiling faces, for the moment feeling he belongs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and David talk; the family visible inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd your pop get hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The factory. An accident. (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's no good to them anymore so they just fired him. He's got no union to protect him. Inside, Esther is singing a lullaby to Les; Mayer calls out to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David?   Time to come in now. Jack looks in at the warm family tableau: the lullaby, Sarah reading to Mayer. David, going in, sees his friend's expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you stay here tonight...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got my own place... but thanks.                      * Your family's real nice, Dave.                         * (beat)                                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like mine.                                             * David nods, climbs in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow. Carryin' the banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carryin' the banner. Jack watches as David rejoins the family inside, the warmth, the casual intimacy. He moves off, singing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack starts down               UP FOR YOU? the fire escape to the alley below.             WHEN I DREAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still singing,               LIKE I'M GONNA LIVE FOREVER Jack drops off the fire      IT'S A FEELING TIME escape into the alley;       CAN NEVER TAKE AWAY moves to the sidewalk        ALL I NEED'S A FEW MORE DOLL and walks off.               AND I'M OUTTA HERE TO STAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack walks the streets,                   JACK past people cooling          WHERE DOES IT SAY in the night air,            YOU GOTTA LIVE AND DIE HERE? outside their hot            WHERE DOES IT SAY tenements.                   A GUY CAN'T CATCH A BREAK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sees two cops                FAMILY coming and instinc-             AIN'T YA GLAD YOU AIN'T T tively hides in the               WAY? shadows, finishing              AIN'T YA GLAD YOU GOT A D the song in the dark.           CALLED SANTA FE...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack approaches the entrance as Racetrack comes down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go at the track, Race?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That hot tip I told you about? Nobody told the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile and continue into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Race pay Kloppman for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed your supper, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we didn't miss much, did we?                     *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ate, Mr. Kloppman, I... (sounds strange to say it) ... I was dinin' with a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Race and Kloppman exchange looks as Jack moves on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack enters the empty room and walks past a row       of basins to the last one. He reaches beneath it,        dis a brick and removes a small box. In the box is        a t Prince Albert Tobacco can -- Jack puts today's       take inside it. Then he removes -- -- a photograph: faded, dog-eared. Against a Coney Island western backdrop, fake cactus, fake fence, a smiling man and woman beam down at a small boy in a cowboy hat -- it's Jack, about Les's age, with his parents. Jack sits hunched under the basin, alone, staring at it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer in his shirt-sleeves glowers impatiently as a prim 1899-vintage numbers cruncher -- JONATHAN -- deliv- ers the bottom line with charts, graphs, etc. Seitz lounges, yawning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actual income, as well as projected income, against actual operating costs, as well as projected operating costs, produce a reduced marginality of profit which in turn --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seitz!   What in blazes is he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says you need to make more money, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I need to make more money! But how do I make more money, you bloodless blot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unflappable) I have several proposals. The first is to increase the paper's price --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Hearst undersells me and I'm in the poorhouse. Brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the customer price -- the price to the distribution apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exasperated, Pulitzer looks to Seitz for a translation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the Newsies...? Charge the Newsies more for their papers? Bad idea, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. My next proposal -- salary cuts, particularly those at the very top --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. What  do the Newsies pay now -- fifty cents per hundred papers? If  you raised it to sixty cents --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mere tenth of a cent per paper --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- then that, multiplied by forty thousand papers a day, seven days a week -- well, it would pay some of the bills around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, if you do this, every Newsie we got will head straight for Hearst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessarily. As newspapermen, Hearst and I would cut each other's throats to get the best of the other. But as businessmen -- and gentlemen -- we often agree on ways to keep down certain operating costs. If I know Willie Hearst, he's going to wish he thought of this himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the other papers -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we do it, they'll all do it. It's only a tenth of a cent -- nobody gets hurt! It's good for the Newsies -- an incentive, make 'em work harder, sell more papers! Now get me Hearst on that contraption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seitz sighs and reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack bounces into the square, still   basking in the glow of last night. He looks up to the    chalkboard and sees the headline: "BLOODY BEATINGS IN    TROLLEY STRIKE!" He grins, gives the high-sign -- a   very salable headlin He moves on to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's wrong -- angry shouts, arms waving.       Puz Jack shoves through the angry Newsies to --

dialogues.speaker: KID BLINK
dialogues.text: They jacked up the price! Ten cents a hunnerd -- I can eat two days on ten cents!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This'll bust me -- I'm barely                           * makin' a livin' now --                                  *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back sleepin' on          * the streets --                    *

dialogues.speaker: MUSH
dialogues.text: It don't make no sense! All the money Pulitzer makes, why would he gouge us? Jack sees Weasel behind his window, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, pipe down! Don't you see it's a gag? Just Weasel bein' a weasel. Joke's over, Wease. Gimme a hunnerd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plops fifty cents on the counter.      Weasel's grin gets weaselier as he slides it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunnerd'll cost ya sixty, Cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't payin' no sixty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then move outta the way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet -- I move right over to the Journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same at the Journal -- we checked -- it's the same everywhere!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the jack-up, Weasel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? It's a nice day. Why don't you ast Mr. Pulitzer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whacks the bell with his cudgel; the Delanceys stir threateningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ain't buyin' papes, clear out! World employees only on this sida the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stinks here anyway -- let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads the angry Newsies out of the courtyard into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The angry boys crowd around Jack.

dialogues.speaker: KID BLINK
dialogues.text: They can't do that to us --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can do what they want -- it's their stinkin' paper --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't we got no rights -- ?

dialogues.speaker: CRUTCHY
dialogues.text: Sure -- we got the right to take it in the t'roat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a rigged deck -- why waste time kiddin' ourselves? They set the price, we gotta pay it --

dialogues.speaker: MUSH
dialogues.text: We got no choice! So let's get our lousy papes while they still got some --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's goin' anywhere -- they ain't gonna get away with this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do -- (etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop crowding him!    Let him think! They back off, become quiet -- every eye on Jack as he thinks. And thinks again. And again. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack...? Ya still thinkin'... ?                        * Jack looks at him, then the others:    his jaw set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing for sure. If we don't sell papes, then nobody sells papes. Nobody comes through those gates 'til they put the price back where it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like a strike...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a strike -- good idea, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) No, I didn't mean -- we can't strike, we're not a union --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go on strike, we're a union, right? Keep it comin', Dave --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's moving across the square, everyone following, cheering, a momentum building. David moves with him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) There's not enough of us -- maybe if we got every Newsie in New York --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we organize -- we get all the New York Newsies to join us! This is great, Dave, keep talkin' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no joke! You saw what happened to those trolley workers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another great idea! Any Newsie don't join with us, we soak 'im -- just like the trolley workers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooo! Stop and think, willya?     You can't just rush everybody into this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang is cheering every word; Jack stops at the base of the Greeley statue, holds up his hands for quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave's right again! We gotta think this through! Old man Pulitzer and Hearst and all them other rich geezers, they run this city. Do we really think a buncha streetrats like us would have a chance against people like them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choice has gotta be yours -- are we gonna just take what they give us? Or do we strike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies are silent, faltering, suddenly uncertain. Then a small figure steps forward and raises his fist:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys explode -- a beat begins to build --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep talkin', Jack -- tell us what to do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks desperately at David:      what do I say now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... uh... Pulitzer and Hearst have to respect our rights --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer and Hearst have to respect the workin' boys of New York! (to David) Keep it comin' -- what else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... they can't treat us like we don't exist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we stick together like the trolley workers, they can't break us up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a union. The Newsboy's Union. Are we really a union...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to stop someone else from sellin' our papes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We talk to 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of 'em don't hear so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we soak 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! We can't beat up kids in the street! It'll destroy what we're trying to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's not listening now.          TO STOP THE SCABBERS?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crutchy hobbles forward, raising his crutch.                       CRUTCHY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack jumps down from the statue.                                   JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps onto the back of a wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two wagonloads of nervous    STARTS RINGING Newsies come through the     WILL WE HEAR IT? gate. Some leap off and join the strikers -- most                NEWSIES stay on the wagon.           NO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Race, Mush and Kid Blink                  ALL leap onto the wagon with     THAT THIS AIN'T NO GAME baskets of rotten fruit.     THAT WE GOT A TON OF ROTTEN singing as a trio.           FRUIT AND PERFECT AIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack steps forward.            SO THEY GAVE THEIR WORD Boots angrily throws a piece of rotten fruit toward The World Building.     BUT IT AIN'T WORTH BEANS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boots, apprehensive, looks up at Jack in the wagon.                    BOOTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and the others jump       PULITZER MAY OWN THE down from the wagon and with   WORLD BUT HE DON'T OWN US! David and Les following, move across the square.                     ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies answer back.                    ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crossing the square, as                       ALL they move towards the gates,   AND   THE WORLD WILL KNOW singing up to Pulitzer's       AND   THE WORLD WILL LEARN office in the dome at the      AND   THE WORLD WILL WONDE top of The World Building.     HOW   WE MADE THE TABLES T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Delanceys close the              THAT    WE HAD TO CH gates as Weasel glares out           THAT    THE THINGS W from the dock.                       WILL    BE TOMORROW'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies interlock arms           AND THE YOUNG STAND forming a chain of                   AND THE TIME IS NOW resistance and solidarity.           AND THE WINDS WILL B

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, excited by his power, is in full charge now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta get word out to all the Newsies in New York! I gotta have some... whattaya call 'em --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambassadors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! You guys gotta be embastards and tell 'em we're on strike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take Harlem!

dialogues.speaker: RACETRACK
dialogues.text: I got mid-town!        CRUTCHY The Bronx!                MUSH I'll get da Bowery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumlet, Specs, Skittery take Queens; Pie Eater and Snotty, the East side -- Snipeshooter, go with 'em; okay, who wants Brooklyn? Spot Conlon's territory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly they all look like they've got something else to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsamatter?    Scared of Brooklyn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't scared of Brooklyn. But Spot Conlon makes us a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he don't make me nervous. You and me, Boots, we take Brooklyn. Dave can keep us company. Okay, Dave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David looks up; Jack grins, challenging him.       David right back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Right after you take our demands to Pulitzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grin fades) Me? (looks up at the dome) To Pulitzer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his turn to grin) You're the leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks at the huge doors of the World Building, steeling himself. He starts for them, then has a thought -- beckons to Les, who runs to join him, thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the kid'll soften him up a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouting encouragement, the Newsies clear a path as Jack and Les march up to the big doors. Jack pounds on them and there's a hush as everyone waits, watching -- includi a handsome, well-dressed man in his thirties, BRYAN DENTO The huge doors swing open like the mouth of a whale and Jack and Les disappear inside. The Newsies cheer. Denton moves next to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going in to present our demands to Pulitzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What demands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies' demands.   We're on strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton looks around, a little amazed.     He takes out a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Denton, New York Sun.   What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious) David...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David.  As in David and Goliath? (off at doors) You really think old man Pulitzer's going to listen to your demands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that instant, the big doors swing open and Jack and Les are spat out like two seeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling back) So's your ol' lady! Tell Pulitzer he needs an appointment with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors slam shut; Denton scribbles, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, David and Les devour a tray of sandwiches as Denton takes notes. Newsmen at other tables glance over curiously as Jack holds forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a mouthful) -- So this snooty mug is sayin', 'You cawn't see Mr. Pulitzer, no one sees Mr. Pulitzer' -- real hoity-toity, you know the type --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also a mouthful) Real hoity-toity --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- So I says, 'I ain't in the habit of transactin' business with no office boy -- tell him Jack Kelly is here to see him now.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when they threw us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't it scare you going up against the most powerful man in New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bravado) Yeah, lookit me, I'm tremblin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton smiles, closes his notebook.    Gets up, handing David a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep me informed -- I want to know everything that happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we really an important story...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's important? A year ago I covered the war in Cuba -- charging up San Juan Hill with Colonel Teddy Roosevelt. A very important story. Now it doesn't seem so important -- except Teddy's our governor and probably on his way to the White House. Is the Newsies' strike important? It all depends on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping him) My name really gonna be in the papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any objections?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as long as you get it right -- Kelly, Jack Kelly. And, Denton? No pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton smiles and shrugs.    David suspects Jack's thinki of Snyder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, David, Boots are walking as we WIDEN OUT to reveal the magnificent bridge against a dawn sky. They all seem a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been to Brooklyn -- have you guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spent a month there one night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Spot Conlon... is he really as bad as they say...? Jack and Boots look at each other and laugh; they keep laughing as they walk along --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say something funny? Come on, tell me -- he bad or not? What's the joke? Tell me, willya? (Etc.) We KEEP WIDENING as the figures get smaller and Jack and Boots keep laughing and David keeps asking about Spot...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a rotted and collapsing pier is a battered sign: "BROOKLYN EXCURSIONS - CLOSED." Hunched under the pier is a tough kid playing a harmonica, his eyes fixed on -- -- Jack, Boots, David as they cautiously approach through the no-man's land of mud and junk. Boys appear like hostile Indians -- behind them, to the side of them, in front of them -- silently escorting them under the pier. David looks very nervous as they are halted, and the harmonica plays a signal, then stops abruptly. From behind some rotting timbers steps a freckled gnome. He looks them up and down, then grins. He is SPOT CONLON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it ain't Jack be nimble, Jack be quick. Jack meets his challenging grin with one of his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're movin' up in the world, Spot -- got a ocean view and everything. Spot and Jack exchange "heh-hehs."   David's getting more nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm hearin' things from little birdies in Harlem and Queens and all over. They're chirpin' in my ear: 'Jackie-boy's Newsies are playin' like they're goin' on strike -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not playing -- we are on strike -- it's -- Spot's eyes click like switchblades in David's direction -- so do his henchmen's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this, Jackie boy?   Some kind of walkin' mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unintimidated) It's a mouth with a brain -- and if you got half-a-one you'll listen. Tell 'im, Davey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David looks at Jack wide-eyed: "Me?" Scared to death, he starts -- as Spot's henchmen begin circling him like jackals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... we started the strike but... we can't do it alone, so... we've been talkin' to Newsies all over the city...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they told me. And what did they tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David looks nervously at the circling henchmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That... they're all waiting to see what Spot Conlon does. That you're the key... (as Spot puffs himself up; David sees an opening) That Spot Conlon is the most respected and... famous... newsie in New York... and probably everywhere else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spot signals the henchmen to stop circling; waits for more, lapping it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... if Spot Conlon joins the strike, they'll join and we'll be unstoppable so you gotta join and ... well... you gotta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trails off.    Spot nods, turns to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. Brains. (hardens) But I got brains, too -- and more than half-a-one. How do I know you punks won't run the first time some goon comes atcha with a club? How do I know you're in it to win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I'm tellin' you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough, Jackie-boy.   You gotta show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away. David and Boots exhale in relief -- but Jack suddenly grabs a rope hanging from the wharf and swings in front of Spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you lost your guts, Spotty- boy -- (as Spot freezes) -- or maybe you traded 'em to some chicken for that beak of yours. (in Spot's face) Maybe you gotta show me you ain't afraid to join the strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murder's in the air: David and Boots are paralyzed; the henchmen are ready to explode. Spot's eyes are locked on Jack's for an excruciating moment -- then Spot grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice try, pal. But that's just what I'm talkin' about. (serious) Show me this strike ain't just some kids do-or-dare, then we'll talk.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a bucket of red paint, Crutchy paints a portrait of Pulitzer on an old bedsheet. Around him, Newsies roll hoops, play marbles, tag, leap-frog, etc. Looks like more of a holiday than a strike. Jack, David, Boots return from Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where's Spot Conlon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks disgustedly at the activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was concerned about us bein' serious -- you imagine that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some Newsies gather around, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: KID BLINK
dialogues.text: Without Spot and the others, there ain't enough of us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we're movin' too soon, maybe we ain't ready --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely should put this off a coupla days, definitely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jack -- you ready?   I'm ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's swinging a picket sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least somebody's got the right idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else is ready for stick-ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears the sign off the stick and swings it like a bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who we kiddin' here. Spot was right. Just a game to these guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jack -- get a loada this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's waving the bedsheet with the scowling devil-mask of "Joe P" painted on it. Jack smiles as Crutchy parades with the banner, the other Newsies begin to notice. Across the square, Denton lounges with his notebook, studying the Newsies as if he, too, were concerned about how serious they are. David watches Crutchy parading with the bedsheet; other Newsies put aside their marbles, hoops, etc., and watch. Sensing a moment, David moves among them, beginning to sing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As David sings,                 DON'T BE AFRAID AND DON'T the others join in.             NOTHING CAN BREAK US They stand waiting,             NO ONE CAN MAKE US arms interlocked, as            GIVE OUR RIGHTS AWAY the gates begin to              ARISE AND SEIZE THE DAY open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES as the gates swing open and wagons loaded with papers, followed by the nervous non-striking Newsies, are revealed. Weasel and the Delanceys carry clubs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Jack signals and Boots, Race and the boys loose a volley of rotten fruit -- With a shrill cry, the Newsies rush into the courtyard and leap onto the wagons -- Denton watches nearby, writing it all down. David moves among the ranks of terrified non-striking Newsies, exhorting them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw down your papers!   Join the strike! (Etc.) Many of them do -- ripping up their papers, shouting -- -- The Delanceys slog through a storm of rotten fruit; cornering some Newsies by the wagons. They're raising their clubs when -- -- Paint begins to dribble onto their heads -- they look up and the whole bucket is dumped in their faces by Crutchy. They lunge for him, dripping -- he ducks away, poking at them with his crutch -- -- Jack and the others toss bundle after bundle of papers from the wagons -- they're torn to shreds, tossed in the air -- a blizzard of newsprint and then: SHRILL POLICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheezit -- the bulls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies scatter through the snowstorm of paper as three mounted policemen gallop into the square -- Crutchy, hobbling as fast as he can, falls -- a large hand snatches him up -- Morris, grinning through the paint. But no one notices as -- The Newsies leap, cheering in triumph, through the drift- ing shreds of paper, as they vanish in all directions --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands at the window with Seitz. Weasel hovers nearby, awestruck in the presence of Pulitzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they're just going to go away, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me the means, Mr. Pulitzer. I'll take care of them for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer turns his godlike gaze on Weasel, who seems to shrink slightly. Pulitzer studies him a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Seitz) Give him whatever 'means' he requires, I want this nuisance over and done with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back down at the square, where Crutchy's crude portrait of him, lying crumpled on the pavement, stares back at him.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark cheerless building looming over an empty street. INTO FRAME step Jack and David, Jack with a rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The House of Refuge... my home- sweet-home...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He crouch-runs across the street David following nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be sure they sent Crutchy here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I be sure the Delanceys stink -- 'cause that's how things work. An orphan gets arrested, Snyder gets him sent here to be 'rehabilitated' -- (lassos a chimneypot on the roof) -- the more kids in the Refuge, the more money the city sends to take care of 'em, and the more Snyder can steal. (starts climbing) He's here alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, looking around nervously, starts climbing after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and David creep along above some large barred windows. Jack loops the rope around his waist, swings over the edge --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David watches from the roof as Jack taps on a window. An inmate, TENPIN, 9, looks up and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowboy!   Ya miss the joint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whattayasay, Tenpin.   You got a new guy, Crutchy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gimp?   I'll get him for ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack takes a railroad spike from his belt and begins prying at the bars, talking conversationally up to David who's terrified someone's going to hear them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Tenpin -- s'posed to get out last Christmas but Snyder keeps tackin' more time on his sentence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shushing frantically) Be quiet -- they'll hear you --!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Crutchy appears, grinning at Jack dangling on the rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, whattaya hangin' around here for? That Dave up there? Hiya, Dave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David pleads for silence.    Jack pries at the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get your hat, Crutch -- kiss Snyder good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evasively) Yeah... hey, shoulda seen me in court today -- old Judge Movealong Monahan hisself! Took him two minutes to move me along to Snyder for 'my own good.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Crutchy -- get your stuff. Crutchy stops Jack's hand prying at the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Jack... truth is, I ain't walkin' so good. Oscar and Morris kinda worked me over a little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hurt you...? Don't worry, we'll carry you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vehemantly) I don't want nobody carryin' me -- never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks up: Crutchy's eyes flash with pride.       The he smiles, softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't so bad here. Get three squares, sorta, and there's some swell fellas... (up to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still talk about how Jack rode outta here on that coach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs; resigned) Teddy Roosevelt's. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already heard the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it's true --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crutchy hears something and quickly shushes them: Jack disappears from the window; Crutchy slumps into a bunk and pretends to sleep -- just as Snyder comes into the room. Utter silence -- -- except for Snyder's FOOTSTEPS as he walks slowly down the aisle between the bunks. He stops at the window, his back to it. Crutchy sneaks open his eyes to see -- -- Jack, behind Snyder, swinging past the window, arms stretched in a balletic arabesque -- -- Crutchy struggles not to laugh; Tenpin and some others see what's going on. They all fight laughter as -- -- Jack swings back and forth behind Snyder, striking difference poses as he passes the window: the breast stroke, running on air, a bird with flapping wings... -- From the roof, David looks down in disbelief: then smiles -- nothing Jack does would surprise him any more. -- Snyder glares suspiciously at the boys, sensing something is going on. Behind him, Jack floats past as an angel -- Snyder wheels around, looks -- -- but the window is empty. Puzzled, he walks out of the room. The instant he's gone, the boys explode in stifled laughter. We MOVE IN ON Crutchy as he laughs until the tears come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and David move down the deserted street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crutchy won't last in there... I seen stronger guys than him not make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you really escape in Teddy Roosevelt's coach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in it.   On it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he doing at the Refuge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runnin' for governor. Showin' his concern, like all pols during elections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy's not like other politicians. He's the biggest hero in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, he's there. I see his fancy coach waitin' for 'im, so I sneaks on top of it. Teddy gets in and he's wavin' goodbye, and all the guys are wavin' goodbye, and Snyder's wavin' -- 'Good-byeeee, Colonel Roosevelt!' So just as we're goin' out the gate, I stands up and -- (waves) 'Good-byeee, Warden Snyder!' It was in the papes and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs; then) He's governor now. I don't understand how he could see that place and not do anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He only seen what Snyder wanted him to -- good food, everything the city pays for that Snyder usually steals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet if he just knew -- I mean, he's a hero --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last year he was a hero.   This year he's a politician.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weasel moves down a line of frightened young scab newsies clutching their papers. He stops in front of -- -- a burly THUG, 20s, and behind him two dozen more, all clutching newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, 'newsies' -- you check the funny papers this morning? The Thugs unfold their paper -- inside are clubs, chains, brass knuckles, saps. In the distance, we hear MUSIC BEGIN: the marching pulse of the strike anthem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we bust faces, we want our                     * money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weasel puts money in their hands as they file past.     T MUSIC is BUILDING and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SONG: SEIZE THE DAY explodes into full energy as Jack and David lead the Newsies across the square towards the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Newsies converge on the gates --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
