dialogues.text: The gates swing open and the young scab newsies file nervously out -- cannon fodder -- as our Newsies line up and wait for them. David leads a chant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join us!   Join us! etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the scabs decide fast -- they throw down their papers and run to the Newsies where they're welcomed with cheers and handshakes -- but then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees something) Look out -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAGON is ROARING out of the gates full-speed -- barrel- ling towards the line of Newsies -- -- the Newsies scatter -- the line breaks as the WAGON ROARS through, and right behind it is -- -- the army of Thugs, charging through the gates with clubs and chains waving --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -- dozens of scattered battles break out as the Newsies fight back as best they can -- Denton watches at the edge of the square -- nearby him are six POLICEMEN, also watching, doing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you stop this -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him coldly) You better move along, mister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton turns, picks up something -- a large camera and tripod. He moves off quickly -- -- scattered skirmishes all over the square -- clubs swing, fists flail -- the Thugs move the Newsies back, trying to box them in -- -- Weasel and the Delanceys, backed up by other Thugs, are forcing Jack, David, Race, Mush, Boots and Blink into a tight circle. The boys fight back as best they can, dodging the brutal clubs and saps. As the circle tightens, Weasel's eyes are gleaming with gloat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike's over, boys. Something seems to sting him in the neck -- he slaps at it as if at a mosquito. Then other Thugs begin slapping -- all over the square, Thugs are slapping and looking around in puzzlement -- then -- -- the BELL CLANGS as it's hit by a good-sized stone. Jack looks up as David points excitedly to the roofs where -- -- It's Brooklyn to the rescue: Spot Conlon's gang is pelting the Thugs with volleys from their slingshots -- and Spot himself is swinging through the air on a chain hoist into the square. He grins as Jack runs up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, ya showed me! Now I'll show you what Brooklyn can do --! The Thugs retreat from the merciless slingshots -- Jack rallies his Newsies and leads a screaming charge as the Thugs hurry behind the gates, closing them. Jack and Spot spit in their palms, shake hands as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSICAL REPRISE:   "SEIZE THE DAY" begins again; jubilant victorious --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack leaps on a loose horse, pulls David up                      ALL and they lead an impromptu    SEIZE THE DAY victory parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police fade away;         SEND OUT THE CALL AND Spectators who have watched it all begin to                    ALL applaud. Many throw           SEIZE THE DAY coins, bills, or show other signs of support...                        BUMLETS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton flashes a photo as MUSIC ENDS and we see --

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUN
dialogues.text: The front page of The Sun  SPINS OFF the press -- a big headline: "THE CHILDREN'S   CRUSADE" and a large picture of the Newsies, with Jack  very prominent. We hear EXCITED CHEERING as we GO  TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boisterous and happy celebration as dozens of Newsies snatch copies of The Sun from Denton as he passes them out --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -- Waiters bring trays of sasparilla and cold cuts -- everybody talks at once --

dialogues.speaker: RACETRACK
dialogues.text: Lookit this -- just lookit this, willya -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's me pitch'a? Where's me pitch'a?         BOOTS

dialogues.speaker: MUSH
dialogues.text: Lookit Jack -- he looks like a general or sumpin'!                                      SPOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen!  Listen up, everybody -- ! (reads) 'Like a small but rising storm, the infant newsboys' union continues to gather force -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, ya write sweet, Denton -- real sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton smiles; Jack is in the center, trying to keep cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'Their leader is a child of the New York streets with a red bandana and a golden tongue, Jack Kelly -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's it say that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop t'inkin' about yaself and let 'im read!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'The latest clash demonstrates that the publishers might do well to reconsider their strategy of just waiting out the strike -- ' (to Denton)                          * That's their plan? To just wait us out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kids. They think   you'll get tired, or bored, or  maybe just too hungry. And with my   colleagues on the other dailies not  allowed to cover you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks pointedly at a group of reporters leaving the restaurant, shame-facedly averting their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- They can just ignore you until you go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't goin' away.   We'll never go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we gotta show 'em -- we gotta do somethin' they can't ignore, somethin' big --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do it up big, all right -- We'll show 'em we ain't tired, or                      * bored, and the hungrier we get, the more we fight -- (as Denton starts writing) We'll have a rally -- every Newsie                     * in New York -- and we're gonna send                    * a message: there's a lot of us and we ain't goin' away -- we'll keep fightin' until doomsday if it means gettin' what's ours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eloquence is spellbinding; the Newsies are silent, looking at him with new respect. Then, from somewhere, there is a smattering of APPLAUSE. They look to see -- -- At the door,      the group of reporters applauding -- guilty applause      maybe, but still applause. One of th takes a dollar      and puts it in the box marked NEWSIES STRIKE FUND --      another follows suit, then another, a another... Jack and the Newsies watch -- then Jack begins to applaud the reporters. The Newsies join in, clapping, whistling, as the reporters hurry out, feeling a little better about themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SNYDER pops a messy eclair in his mouth -- from a large platter of them -- as he glances at the New York Sun. Crutchy, with a featherduster, is eyeing the eclairs when he sees the picture in the Sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Jack -- ! Hey, he looks just like hisself! Snyder looks at the picture:    instant recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this boy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him?   Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smarmy smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a famous friend, this 'Jack.'... Do you know where he lives...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never seen the guy, honest. (hits his head with his palm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This brain of mine, always makin' mistakes. Got a mind of its own. He hobbles out quickly.    Snyder looks at him, eyes narrowing.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 90

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A juggler struggles on stage. Medda, waiting to go on, checks her makeup as Jack and David talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlings, I love you -- I wish you luck on your rally, I am behind you one hundred percent. But I'm not running a union hall here -- this is a theater, a temple of art. And well-known money pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got money, Medda.      Some, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: 90A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: David sees him take money out of the Prince Albert can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take a collection at the door. We'll pay whatever you ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the money. I depend on the papers. They write good things about me, the customers flock here like sheep. They give me the pan, I'm the one who gets sheared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid of them, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medda's gotta look out for herself same as anybody. We'll find another place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can they make a whole city afraid? We're the ones putting our necks on the line -- all we need is for somebody to have the guts to stand up and show them we're not alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have the power to destroy people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't destroy you if you fight them -- only if you let them own you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You are so young...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back out at the stage; Jack pulls David away. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to be on Monday night.   I'm dark on Monday nights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks at her, smiles. He tries to put his money in her hand: she refuses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it, Medda. Please...?                     * (as she does,                          * reluctantly)                          * Thanks.                                        *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't thank me. Thank Mr. Wisenheimer Guilt-maker of 1899 there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winks at David and moves off to the stage.   Stricken to the core, David watches her begin to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mush painstakingly charcoals "NEWSIES RALLY -- IRVING HALL" on a piece of cardboard. Newsies are scattered in the lobby making handbills, signs, posters. Kloppman comes in and stops short, seeing a dark figure at his counter, going through his register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? The figure turns -- Snyder smiles his smarmy smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a 'Jack Kelly' registered here? I wish to see him. The boys look up, alert.   Kloppman dislikes Snyder on sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Jack Kelly...?' Any of you boys know a 'Jack Kelly'?

dialogues.speaker: SNIPESHOOTER
dialogues.text: Unusual name for these parts.                  SKITTERY I knew a Jack somebody once. Prob'ly not the same guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Jack Kelly -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Snyder, they see Jack bouncing in the front door. Racetrack tries to signal him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- He was here but he put an egg in his shoe and beat it. Jack sees Snyder -- but instead of running back out the door, he can't resist mocking him behind his back. The Newsies snicker; Kloppman is dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have reason to believe he's an escaped prisoner. Possibly dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear me... dangerous? My files are in the rear -- this way, please.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He tries to move Snyder away, silently imploring Jack to go -- but Jack takes his time, picks up a leaflet, elabo- rately approves it, pockets it and strolls out, blowing good night kisses. The Newsies crack up -- Snyder wheels around suspiciously. Racetrack thrusts a leaflet in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (palm extended) Give to the Newsies strike fund, mista?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder tries to look around the leaflet -- then it catches his eye: "RALLY AGAINST PULITZER." He takes it thoughtfully, making a connection. Smiling dangerously, he digs out a penny and drops it in the surprised Racetrack's hand.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: & 93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orange glow of a sunrise is reflected in the window. Sarah appears inside, in a modest nightgown. She opens the window and breathes in the morning air. Then she sees Jack hunched against the wall on the fire escape, shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Did you sleep there?    Why didn't you wake us up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't wanna disturb nobody... anyway, it's like the Waldorf out here... great view, cool air --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances back in the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go up on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pops back inside.    He shrugs, climbs onto --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stretches, shadow-boxes:       something crackles in pocket -- the rally leaflet.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He's looking at it thoughtfully as Sarah climbs up behind him in a shawl, with a bundle. She sees the leaflet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all getting so big. The family's very worried about the boys. And you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mom and pop are worried about me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) The whole family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She unfolds the bundle to reveal a breakfast of bread and milk. He digs in hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David says you're moving away when the strike's over. To Santa Fe. I've never been out of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chewing) You'd like it out there -- they got this big yellow desert and the air's real blue, see, from the sky, and the sun, it's bigger out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) It's the same sun as here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No, it ain't... (beat) Not that I been there or nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess your parents wrote you about it. Bet you can't wait to see them again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks away) Sure... big family reunion. Soon's I get the dough for train fare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David said you spent all your money to rent the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you and Dave don't do nothin' but talk about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I blame you -- me bein' such an interestin' guy and all --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Are you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're smiling, their faces close; for an instant, a kiss seems inevitable. But suddenly a gust of wind catches the leaflet and sails it off the rooftop. Jack lunges for it -- knocking over the milk, squashing the bread with his elbow. He looks up at her sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I tell ya -- interestin', right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah giggles.       The leaflet gyrates in the wind as w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another leaflet reading "RALLY AGAINST PULITZER" (the one Snyder took at Kloppman's) is in Pulitzer's hands as he listens to MAYOR VAN WYCK, very nervous. Nearby is POLICE CHIEF DEVERY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweating) Of course the city is very concerned that this, uh, event doesn't get out of hand, but... Chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't just charge in and break it up, Mr. Pulitzer -- we got no legal cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer looks as if he knows something they don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would the fact that this rally is organized by an escaped criminal be cause enough, Mayor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An escaped criminal...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fugitive from one of your prisons, Mayor -- a convicted thief who's been at large for some time under the alias of 'Jack Kelly.' His real name is...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder slinks out of a corner, humble in such august company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sullivan, Your Honor -- Francis Sullivan. I would have caught him before now but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Warden Snyder, don't you, Mayor? I believe you appointed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor nods ruefully; not one of his best appoint- ments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this boy is a fugitive, then the chief can quietly arrest him and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quietly -- I want an example made. I want this rabble he's roused to see what happens to those who dare to -- well, they should see justice in action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrest him at the rally?   But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, Mayor, I'm having a few friends for cards that night -- newspaper friends, Willie Hearst, Gordon Bennett. Perhaps you'll join us -- we can talk about the coming election.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too eager) I'd be honored... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer dismisses them and they start out, Snyder oozing backwards, the Mayor now all business with Chief Devery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, when you arrest this Kelly, you'd better go in force -- in case some of his misguided friends should start any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they go, Pulitzer picks up his magnifying glass and examines the leaflet. We CUT AWAY as he stares through the glass so he seems to be looking at --

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: & 98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boots FILLS the SCREEN as he shouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extry, extry -- Newsies take Noo Yawk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swarms of excited Newsies engulf Boots as     he pretends hawk the imaginary headline. They cascade      toward the entrance where Jack and David shake hands,     slap backs they flow past. Kloppman goes past, then      Denton. Sar and Les are nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Denton -- sit down front! You're the guest of honor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I'm working press tonight. (looks around) The only working press. As usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you keep writing about us, they're gonna know we exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys swarm into the seats, filling the theater -- down front, the pit band plays a spirited tune. 4/19/91 CHERRY                                      72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as a butler passes cigars in a silver humidor to five men in formal clothes around a table as Pulitzer breaks the seal on a deck of cards. The Mayor is next to him. The room is cavernous, austere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the boys, Mayor -- Mr. Bennett of The Tribune, Mr. Taylor of The Times, of course you know Mr. Hearst -- and this is a new member of our little group, Mr. Gammon, who just came back from Europe... GAMMON, a portly fop in muttonchops, shakes the Mayor's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gammon owns The New York Sun.                     * They all light cigars as Pulitzer begins to deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is packed. The band plays and a thundering cheer goes up as Jack, David, and Spot Conlon leap on the stage. Jack raises his hand and the noise subsides, the band stops. Everybody looks at Jack -- expectant silence. He lets it build for a moment, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carryin' the banner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a roar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carryin' the banner! The noise threatens to blow the roof off the theater as we see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column of mounted police clip-clop down the cobble- stones. The CHEERING from the theater, blocks away, is FAINT in the night air...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise subsides and Jack speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come a long way but we ain't there yet -- and maybe it's only gonna get tougher from now on! That means we get tougher too -- (as a huge roar goes up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- it also means we get smarter! That's why we're gonna listen to my pal David and stop soakin' the scabs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!    They asked for it -- etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta we s'pose to do -- kiss 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I personally wouldn't go that far, Race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any scab I see, I soak 'em -- period!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just what they want you to do -- so they can say we're just thugs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what they say -- some of us ain't made to just take it! I say anybody hurts us, we hurts them worst! Who's with me? A large faction roars in agreement; arguments break out as --

dialogues.speaker: BY ENTRANCE DOORS
dialogues.text: Sarah stands next to Denton and Kloppman. Behind them, the door cracks and in slides Snyder. Kloppman sees him and whispers urgently to Denton, who starts moving after him.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Loud voices, fists starting to fly, chaos --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- start fightin' each other! Prove what the big shots say is true -- we're street rats with no brains and no respect for nothin' -- includin' ourselves! (as they quieten) Here's how it is: we don't stick together, we're nothin'. We don't trust each other, we're nothin'. We don't act together, we're nothin' -- and we might as well go back to the streets where we belong. What's it gonna be? (looks at Spot) Whattaya say, Spot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks out at the crowd; the expectant faces, waiting, afraid it's all going to fall apart. Then back at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say... what you say... I say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spits in his palm and they shake. A huge roar goes up and the boys thrust their hands up in triumph -- but the applause isn't for them but for the curtain rising behind them revealing the dazzling vision of Medda, who walks smiling downstage and begins --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Newsies -- what's new? They roar; Racetrack's on his feet --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Medda, anytime you're off to the races, remember -- I got all the winners!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all winners here tonight, Racetrack. Just being with you makes me feel kinda extra extra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("fainting") I'm dead, I'm in Heaven -- somebody gimme a harp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you never know what life will bring. Over the years, I've developed quite an outlook --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooo, lookout for that outlook!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all kinds of people are always asking my advice, well, for instance -- (CONTINUES - SONG)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medda moves through the crowd:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys sing as sweet as songbirds. MUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit me, I'm a bird, I'm flyin', I'm flyin' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful, Medda, I tellya, I never heard such beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering a blue marble) My prettiest one, Medda -- it's like your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moved; kisses him) Thank you, Boots. Would you keep it for me? For luck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boots beams happily as she moves to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medda, whattayasay -- you and me, Saratoga. We catch the races, maybe a nightclub -- (off her expression) I'm dreamin', huh? It's some other guy -- right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so, Race...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to a little boy and sings --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys boo and hiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medda and dance girls start it but the boys quickly join in -- belting out the lyrics with one great swelling voice, together, celebrating --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The happy song roars inside the theater as the mounted police begin to form a half-circle around the entrance. A paddy wagon clops up and some foot police dismount, among them Officer MacSwain whom we met before.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 111 4/8/91 YELLOW                                        75C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weasel, the Delanceys, roll up in two wagons, each filled with club bearing goons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG fills the hall as Jack, happy and proud, sees Sarah smiling at him, reaches out his hand and pulls her on stage. David is watching this when someone signals him -- Denton, who points his finger at -- Snyder    edging closer to Jack, checking the time on his pocket    watch. He has something in his  hand -- a tin police    whistle. He puts it to his lips  and is about t blow it    when Denton moves up behind him and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you Warden Snyder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder nearly swallows the whistle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Denton of The Sun. I've heard about your work with young people. I wonder if you'd agree to an interview?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder blinks at him, glances at his watch, then lowers his police whistle, smiling modestly.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: David tries to move to Jack to warn him but Race and the others have formed a chorus line and drag him into it. David shouts over the song --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack -- you've gotta get out of here! Snyder! (as Jack cups his ear) Snyder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack can't hear over the song but Snyder does --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interviewing) Is it Snyder as in 'snide'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furious, Snyder blows the police whistle for all he's worth. Instantly police burst in from every door -- all converging on Jack. Immediately he leaps off the stage into the arms of several boys below -- then fights his way out the front door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack rushes out and slides to a stop -- -- the mounted police form a half-circle cutting him off -- and from behind them, Weasel, the Delanceys, and the Thugs move through the horses towards him. Jack has no choice -- he turns and races back into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack darts past the cops back down the aisle where -- Snyder is waiting for him at the foot of the stage, crouched like a football player. As he starts to pounce on Jack --

dialogues.speaker: 114A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -- David flies off the stage onto his back -- Snyder stumbles around as David hangs on in a wild piggyback ride. A cop pulls him off and hurls him to the floor -- -- Sarah screams, seeing what's happened to David -- Les, sobbing, kicks furiously at the cop's leg. Sarah pulls her little brother away as -- -- Weasel and his thugs burst in the doors, clubs swinging. The Newsies scatter, try to escape -- but at each exit door more cops are moving in -- -- Denton, horrified, shouts at the cops to stop -- a thug cracks him on the head and he staggers, bloodied... -- Spot, Race, Boots dart into the wings and start working the pull ropes -- -- Cops converge on Jack at the foot of the stage, backing away, he leaps on stage desperately looking around when he hears behind him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show's over, Cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to see Weasel and   the Delanceys grinning at hi clubs in their hands. They    start toward him and sudden disappear -- straight down   the trap door that's suddenl opened beneath their feet.    Jack sees Spot at a lever i the wings --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtain goin' up, Jack -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Race and Boots jerk the ropes of the fire curtain and Jack leaps for it as it starts to rise --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to reach the skylight -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops leap for Jack's legs as he rises above them heading up into the flies. He hangs on, thrusts one fist into the air and shouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carryin' the banner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the theater, the battered Newsies cheer, heartened. Cops are trying to herd them out -- -- David cheers, pulls for Jack as he watches him rise -- Officer MacSwain has David by the arm -- suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: 114A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -- Weasel, climbing out of the trap, hurls his cudgel -- it sails end over end and -- -- Hits Jack in the side -- he plummets into the mass of cops and is engulfed in blue uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: 114B IN WINGS
dialogues.text: David, chased by MacSwain, races across the stage and up the dressing room stairs. MacSwain nabs him, they're struggling; suddenly, at the top of the stairs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the grand lady) Unhand that boy this instant! (as MacSwain looks up, startled) I said hands off the kid, you red- faced baboon! Get out of my theater -- out, out, out, out, out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David twists away as MacSwain backs stumblingly down the stairs as Medda descends on him in full fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're tired of beating up children, maybe you'd like to try a lady next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confused and intimidated, the Irish cop looks at her -- then ducks his head shamefacedly and moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run, David, hurry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got Jack --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't help him if you're in jail, too! You were right, David -- you've got to keep fighting them -- always. (kisses him) Now go. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David looks at her, very moved, then goes. She turns back to her theater -- the sounds of the melee sweep over her. She watches, tears welling in her eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dingy room filled with dusty light.   A BAILIFF announces --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awrise, awrise, court is now in session, Judge E.A. Monahan presiding. Weasel is in the gallery as JUDGE MOVEALONG MONAHAN, hungover, winding a pocket watch, takes the bench and glances down at a group of battered Newsies, including Spot, Race, and Boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of you represented by counsel? No? Good. That'll move things along considerably. David sees Denton come in, a neat bandage on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Movealong, ya honor, I object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what grounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the grounds of Brooklyn, ya honor! The Newsies congratulate Spot.    Monahan gavels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fine you each five dollars or two weeks confinement in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five bucks!   We ain't got five cents!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay the fines. All of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay the clerk. Next. The Newsies mob Denton boisterously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, I owe ya, you're a right                       * guy, Denton, etc.                                      *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subdued) Meet me at the restaurant, all of you. We have to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk and eat, right? On you, huh, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh and clap his shoulders as he looks uncomfort- able. Suddenly David gasps, seeing Jack led out in shackles, his face bruised and swollen. Everybody stares, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, fellas! Hey, Denton -- guess we made all the papes this time, huh? How'd my picture look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of the papers covered the rally. Not even The Sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is stunned, David bewildered, as Denton turns abruptly and leaves the courtroom. The Bailiff shoves Jack in front of the bench. Snyder slips in from a side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Case of Jack Kelly, inciting to riot, assault, resisting arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Monahan, I'll speak for this young man --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock surprise) You two know each other?   Ain't that nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just move it along, Warden Snyder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boy's real name is Francis Sullivan; mother deceased; father a convict in the state penitentiary --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, the Newsies, are stunned as Snyder continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is currently an escapee from the House of Refuge, where his original sentence of three months for theft was extended six months for disruptive behavior --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Like demandin' you give us the food you steal from us --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Followed by an additional six months for an attempted escape --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting tears) -- Last time wasn't no attempt, remember, Snyder? Me and Teddy Roosevelt wavin' bye-bye --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Therefore, I ask that he be returned to the House of Refuge --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- For my own good, right, Movealong? -- and for what Snyder kicks back to ya --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And that the court order his incarceration until the age of twenty-one --

dialogues.speaker: DAVID/NEWSIES SNYDER
dialogues.text: (on their feet)                  -- In the hope that we No! You can't do that!              may yet guide him to No! Etc.                            useful and productive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So ordered.   Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies shout angrily as Jack is led away, struggling. Weasel slips out the door, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, Spot, Race, Mush, Boots, Blink pick dispiritedly at a plate of knockwurst. Les, hungry as always, finishes a large sausage and takes another as he listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't be there long -- the jail ain't built that Jack can't bust outta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're buildin' some mighty good jails these days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where's Denton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he'd be here. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't let this stop us. We gotta keep the strike going, just like Jack was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the sad truth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but Jack ain't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know that, genius -- if he was here, he'd be tellin' us what to do when he ain't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gets up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bummers is givin' me a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'? We need you. Spot sighs:   he hates having to explain the obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nachally  Spot Conlon is needed wherever  -- which right now is Brooklyn.   Some of my boys is worried,  I must give ear to their concerns  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slams fist in his palm) -- and reassure them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts out, he passes Denton, coming in. Denton hardly notices him as he moves up to the table and is greeted (AD LIB) by the boys. He seems grim, bitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't The Sun print the story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it never happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never happened; whattaya mean?   Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's not in the papers, then it never happened. The owners decreed that it not be in the papers, therefore... (beat) I just came to tell you fellows goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange puzzled looks.    David sees Denton's expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton, what's happened -- you get fired or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton forces a breezy tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reassigned -- back to my old job as The Sun's ace war correspondent. The owner thinks I should be covering only the 'really important' stories. So wish me luck, boys. At least half what I wish you. (to David) They don't always fire you, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves off; David, stunned, hurries after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They bought you off... didn't they? Didn't they!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could've blackballed me from every paper in the country. I'm a newspaperman, I have to have a paper to write for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at David; hurt, betrayed, angry; wishes there was more he could say. He hands him something from his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the story I wrote about the rally. I want you to read it at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands it to David and   goes. David returns to the others, angrily crumpling   the story and hurling it onto the table. The boys look    puzzled; Les, still eating the sausage, picks up the   story and looks at it curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (decisively)                                     * We bust Jack out of the Refuge                          * tonight. From now on, we depend                         * on nobody but the Newsies.                              *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David leads Spot, Blink, Boots, Mush, Race as they crouch and creep along the wall. Spot carries a rope. David looks up, searching for a window. Indicates one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where we saw Crutchy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to throw up the rope when Boots hisses from the corner, beckoning furiously. They hurry over and peek around the corner to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carriage is waiting. The boys watch as a door opens and two figures emerge. One is Snyder, the other is Jack. They get into the carriage and it starts toward the boys -- who quickly duck out of sight as it CLIP- CLOPS past and enters the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where they takin' him...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One way to find out.   Meet me back at the square!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David runs after the carriage, leaping onto its back. He flashes the high-sign to the boys as the carriage moves off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David hangs on to the back of the carriage, peering around to see some huge stone gates as it moves into a circular drive and stops. He sees a figure waiting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David watches as Jack is led inside by Snyder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A butler leads Seitz, Snyder and Jack across a marbled floor, their FOOTSTEPS ECHOING in the luxurious hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very impressive. So where do they keep the trains in this station?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seitz shows   him into an elegant library. Snyder tries t follow but   Seitz stops him, closing the doors. Inside, Jack looks   around to see the imposing figure of Pulitze staring at   him, framed by luxurious furnishings. For a moment, the   two just stare at each other. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Sorry to see you ain't doin' so good, Joe.                                             *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Driver strolls around the rear of the carriage -- just as David slips beneath it and begins to crawl care- fully toward the front. Finding the lynch-pin that hitches the horses to the carriage, he reaches for it -- just as the horse snorts and pulls the carriage forward a few steps. The Driver hurries back to the reins. With the Driver's boots a few inches from his face, David waits for another chance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer paces, watching Jack look at the books, the art, at framed front pages; headlines of the world's great events...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what I was doing when I was your age? I was in a war. The Civil War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard of it. You win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People think wars are about right and wrong. They're not. They're about power. You know what power is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard of that, too.   I don't just sell ya papes, Joe.   Sometimes I read 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer ignores the impudence, continues quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power means that I could see to it that you serve your full sentence at the Refuge. Or I could pull strings and have you free tomorrow. It means I could give you my pocket change -- and you'd have more money than you'd likely ever earn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bribin' me, Joe? Thanks for the compliment, but I ain't got the power to stop the strike --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I disagree. You're the spirit of the strike, without you, they'd fall apart in a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ring for my coach, willya?   It's past my bedtime --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth and listen ! (as Jack looks up, startled) You're going to do exactly as I say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- or what? You'll send me back to the Refuge? I'll bust out again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and be a fugitive who's pursued and caught and returned. I'm offering you a choice -- is that what you choose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told ya... I can't call off the strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to. All I ask is that you return to your old job -- as Newsie for the The World.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And be a scab? Forget it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a few days. Then the strike ends -- and it will end, boy, make no mistake -- and you can go wherever you want to buy a ticket. Free and clear, with money in your pocket... and no one chasing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is silent, troubled.    Pulitzer pushes a buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go back to the Refuge. Think it over in your cell. Let me know in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is hiding by the gates with the lynch-pin in his hand. Snyder is waiting by the carriage. The front door opens -- Seitz and Jack walk out and appear at the top of the entrance stairs. David calls out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack is surprised. He looks at Snyder and Seitz, pulls away from Seitz, slides down a bannister, and leaps to the ground. Snyder lunges for Jack, who manages to evade Snyder's reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the driver) After him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver whips the horse forward but is jerked off his seat as the carriage separates. The horse runs off. Amidst the confusion, David and Jack tear through the gates way ahead of Snyder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping up to Snyder) Don't worry. He's got no place to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the pillar, Jack stops running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why're you stoppin' -- we've got to run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't'a done this, David. They could put you in jail --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worth it -- let's go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to jail, what happens to your family? You don't know nothin' about jail! Thanks for what you done, but you gotta get outta here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't either -- I don't understand nothin' no more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack pushes David down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go!

dialogues.speaker: 128A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: David looks over his shoulder and runs off, leaving Jack alone on the street. Jack steps into the shadows as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack steps back into the light, the CAMERA WIDENS and we realize he's back in the House of Refuge. Jack begins to sing softly: REPRISE: "SANTA FE." Jack sits in a small dark room -- an isolation room; moonlight shines through barred windows; there's a door with a small serving panel in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks up as the serving panel opens and Crutchy peers through, offering him something furtively: a boiled potato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snitched it offa Snyder's plate when I was servin' him -- the biggest one! (as Jack shakes his head, looks away) Snyder was eatin' good tonight -- the stuff we don't never get? Patatas... olives... (mouth watering) ... liver and bacon. Sauerkraut... (grins) Guess what I done to his sauerkraut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) So what's it git'cha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anudder three months, prob'ly. But you can't let 'em beat'cha, right, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We was beat when we was born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crutchy, concerned, hears something and closes the panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks at the            WILL YOU KEEP A CANDLE moonlight shining               BURNIN'? through the bars...          WILL YOU HELP ME FIND MY

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 140

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies chant at the crowd in the courtyard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop The World -- don't scab, stop The World -- don't scab, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David moves among them, looking like a leader now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody sells a pape today -- we're hurtin' them and they know it! Remember -- no soakin', no hittin' -- etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gates open, the wagons start out, followed by nervous scabs flanked by cops and goons. The chant builds as the scabs parade by, then suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... I'm seein' t'ings... tell me I'm seeing t'ings -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and the others look in disbelief -- walking with the scabs is Jack, wearing a tight new suit, flanked by Weasel and other goons. As Jack moves past, staring straight ahead, the chant dies...

dialogues.speaker: RACETRACK
dialogues.text: What's he doin' with the scabs...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't happenin'... it can't be happenin'...

dialogues.speaker: BOOTS
dialogues.text: Where'd he get them clothes -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he passes) Mr. Pulitzer picked 'em out hisself. A special gift to a special new employee. Only not so new, huh, cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sold us out! Ya dirty scab, I'll murder ya -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spot tries to bust through the goons but they hurl him back. David, confused, angry, runs alongside Jack, shouting across the smirking Weasel as they march along --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is why you wouldn't escape last night -- why'd you do it? Talk to me, you liar! What else did he give you to sell us out -- money? What else? Look at me! (as Jack keeps walking) You lie about everything -- headlines, your family -- (as Jack keeps look- ing straight ahead) -- because nobody counts but you -- nobody or nothing! Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David lunges for him and Weasel grabs him, hissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be lookin' for you, wiseguy -- (grins) -- or maybe you'd like a nice new suit of your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David twists away, tries to rally the Newsies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep after them -- we don't need him! (starts the chant) Stop The World -- don't scab! Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some chant halfheartedly, confused, demoralized. A few toss down their picket signs in disgust. David moves among them, desperately trying to keep the chant going. The scabs move on, passing Les, who gives Jack a stricken look as he moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) He's just foolin' 'em... so he can spy on them or something... (with certainty) That's it. He's spyin' on 'em. He's gotta be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sits in the window, brooding.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mayer is removing the bandage from his injured hand, helped by Les. Sarah and Esther work on lace piecework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That hand is not ready to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayer flexes his fingers, pale from being bandaged so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready or not, it can handle a broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets his coat; Sarah, looking for something, finds a stained paper package under a sewing basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up the package distastefully) What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- I'm saving that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the package and unwraps it -- revealing a half- eaten knockwurst -- throwing the wrapping on the floor. Irritably Sarah starts to throw it away when she sees it has writing on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be too hard on your friend. Maybe he had his reasons for doing what he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chewing knockwurst) I told you. He's spyin' on 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.   You see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayer smiles and goes.     Sarah moves to David with the stained papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Denton's story. 'The Dark Truth: Why Our City Really Fears the Newsie Strike, by Bryan Denton. Last night I saw naked force exercised against mere boys, the Newsies, who earn at best a few pennies a day. I wondered why so much, against so little -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David refuses to listen; he angrily steps out on the fire escape and stares off into the city. Sarah keeps reading to herself. What she reads disturbs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang looks sullenly at the door where Kloppman is ushering in two policemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will only be a minute.   Please, no trouble. A policeman stands aside and Jack enters, in the new suit. Utter silence. The police escort him the length of the dorm and into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack goes straight to his hiding place and removes the box. He looks inside and is startled -- -- a dead rat is inside the box, covered with tiny pieces of the photograph with his family. His money is gone. He tosses the box aside; his eyes hardening. The police escort him back into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few snickers as he moves toward his bed. Racetrack stands holding a bundle of Jack's belongings: he shoves it into Jack's chest and does his Delancey routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear me, what is dat unpleasant aroma -- ? (as Jack's fists clench)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, take a shot -- I bust your scab face, ya yellow-livered,                           * rotten stinkin' piecea garbage!                         * Jack just looks at him, unclenches his fists. He moves for the door, as one by one the Newsies turn their backs on him.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 151

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BIG PRESSES POUND RHYTHMICALLY somewhere O.S. in the building. A candle illuminates Weasel's gloating face as he leads Jack down a flight of RICKETY STAIRS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the noise) Mr. Pulitzer says nothin' but the best for you, cowboy. He takes care of his loyal employees -- and he's put me personally in charge of seein' that you stay a loyal employee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a door and they enter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weasel lights a lantern and Jack sees a wooden bed, an old printing press, junk, all covered with dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You try any tricks, and I go straight to Mr. Pulitzer. (grins) Will you be requirin' anything else? Then I bid you good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. The great PRESSES THUNDER heavily somewhere in the building above, like a judgment. Jack looks at the bleak room, buried in dust and noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the other scabs, Jack steps up for his papers. Weasel shows his usual charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep well, cowboy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack ignores him, moves off with his papers. The Delanceys pass by; Morris grinning at him, bouncing a club in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come wit' us, cowboy -- we're gonna fix your pal Davey today -- fix 'im so's he can't walk no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shuddup!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backhands Morris in the chops and they move on.    Jac starts after them, alarmed -- then he sees Weasel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift one finger... and you're right back in the Refuge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stops, torn.    He nods meekly, moves off.   Weasel looks satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, with a basket of lacework, is coming down the street, Les dawdling behind, in a bad mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, come on -- you're supposed to be helping me today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sulking) I'd rather be soakin' scabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops to kibbitz a game of marbles in an alley. Sarah walks on -- suddenly a man steps in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) 'Scuse me, sweetface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to step around him but Morris is there. He "accidentally" knocks her lacework into the gutter. Les sees it -- and races towards the Delanceys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from my sister!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flails at Morris -- who effortlessly shoves him flat on his bottom and turns, grinning, to Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's ya brudder, tootsie? Where's little Davey...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) You... stupid... ape!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On "ape," she socks him square in the grin -- he recoils, licking a bloody lip. Behind him, she sees David rounding the corner --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!   Run -- get away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar grabs Sarah from behind and lifts her up, taunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, run, Davey! We got the best parta ya family right here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, furious, runs down the sidewalk towards them. Morris slips on some brass knuckles in anticipation. Sarah struggles, screaming --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, no -- don't -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar hangs on to Sarah, enjoying himself -- suddenly, from behind, two hands grab the rim of his derby and jerk it down to the bridge of his nose. Blinded, he releases Sarah and staggers around, trying to pry the hat off his eyes. Les looks up to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack flashes him a grin        as he works on Morris's br basket. Just as Oscar         frees himself from the derb David leaps on him like        a fury. Punches fly and th Delanceys beat a quick        retreat down the sidewalk, back --

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Ya better run, cowboy -- we're tellin' Weasel! You'll be back in the Refuge by supper time!                                 OSCAR But they're the ones running. David, catching his breath, looks at Jack, beginning to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't stay away, huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I can't be somethin' I ain't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scab...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.    Smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack shrugs, smiles.      David looks at him worriedly. )O(    4/25/91 GREY   A97A.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 158
dialogues.text: thru                      thru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, David, Sarah thoughtfully on the escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without you, the strike's falling apart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got no choice. I stay here, they lock me up 'til I'm twenty- one. Les clambers out with a pair of Mayer's cast-off high- button shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, for the trip -- a pair of cowboy boots! Sorta. Mayer with a bundle of clothes; Esther with food come to the window. She gives it to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows what's to eat where you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives the clothes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few things of mine and David's. Wish we had money to give you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very moved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who needs it...? I go down to the train yards, hop me a freight, go in the best style -- free...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's waiting for you in Santa Fe, but you'll always have family here. They embrace him and move away. An awkward moment -- Jack picks up the bundle to go and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (decisively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to run away. They'll just come after you. You have to fight them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got it all wrapped up, Sarah and nothin' I can do is gonna make one bit of difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wrong. You touched people you don't even know about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She removes the stained pages from her shawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton's story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton looked out for hisself just like I gotta do -- so save it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just listen! 'The men who run this city are terrified of the Newsies strike -- because other child laborers in the factories and sweatshops are hearing the message of the Newsies leader --'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's you!   He's writin' about you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'In the voice of Jack Kelly, these children hear strength and pride. Most of all, they hear hope...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack listens questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can these words really be about him...?     As we GO TO -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton reads his own words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ' -- And that is what terrifies the powers-that-be, for they know our city thrives on the shame of child labor. Therefore, Jack Kelly's voice must be stopped, whatever the cost... (stops) Damn good writing, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: 160D CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack has listened somberly, moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All them sweatshop kids are listenin' to me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think if the Newsies can do it, why can't they? All they need is a leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minute I show my face, I'm back in the Refuge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have help this time. I've been investigating the Refuge -- I know somebody who's going to be very interested in Snyder's little racket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) What happened to the ace war correspondent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This war'll do for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever happens, it's Jack's decision. He's the one in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look expectantly as he stares off, deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack...?   You thinkin'...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I'm thinkin' of Newsie Square full of kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks it up) ... Another rally, right under Pulitzer's nose, and not just the Newsies --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Every workin' kid from every sweatshop in New York. We gotta get the word out -- let's go get the Newsies -- (catches himself) They still think I'm a scab...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell 'em you was a spy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you gonna reach all these people? No paper in New York will print anything about the strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're Newsies, ain't we?   So we make our own paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet and let me think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whattaya need to start a paper? Writers, right? So we got Denton. What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advertisements! (as they look at him) Cartoons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the cold facts) A printing press. And no paper or printer is going to defy Pulitzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others look discouraged; Jack's thinking again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les. Go set me straight with the Newsies, okay? Tell 'em to meet us later at the World Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les races off on his mission; the others look question- ingly at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So happens I know a guy with a printing press.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 165

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge PRESSES pound out papers; a LOUD THUDDING rhythm shakes the building --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The THUDDING rhythm seems very near. Jack leads Sarah, David, Denton, Les down the rickety stairs with a candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're  right above us -- and if Weasel  catches us, it won't be just me  they'll throw in the slammer  -- They can barely hear over the DIN of the PRESSES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said shhhh! -- or we all go to jail! The others shush him hastily; MUSIC BEGINS as they go into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton heads straight for the old press, checking it over expertly. Jack directs the others to ink, paper, etc., as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --                                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denton finds the type- font: David is ready to ink the rollers. A NOISE O.S. makes them freeze. Jack puts his finger to                      DENTON his lips; hoists Les up to     WHO'S THAT? the window to be a lookout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David tosses some candles to Sarah; she lights them                    DAVID for Denton as he works.        NICE CATCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack finds a roll of newsprint.                                  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THAT'S IT YOU'RE GETTING IT KEEP IT STEADY ALMOST READY JACK    WON'T BE LONG 'TIL SOMEBODY

dialogues.speaker: CHOKE IT GUESSES
dialogues.text: THEY GOT PROWLERS INKING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIGHT OR WRONG WE'RE ON THE LAM NOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOO LOUD!   SOMEONE'S OVER US!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIGHT OR WRONG AIN'T WORTH A DAMN NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOO LATE, GOTTA FINISH IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE'RE AT THE POINT OF NO RETURN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the above, Sarah holds a candle for Denton as he sets a headline in very large type: HOW WE CAN SHOW THIS CITY -- David has a better idea: he grabs some type and resets the headline: HOW WE CAN STOP THIS CITY. Meanwhile, Jack hits the switch and the PRESS HUMS to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY'RE HITCHIN' ON A TROLLEY RIDIN' ON A WAGON STOWIN' ON THE FERRY COME TO SLAY THE DRAGON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND SHEEPSHEAD BAY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSTRUMENTAL break.             *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND THE WORLD WILL KNOW AND OUR RANKS WILL GROW AND THE WORLD WILL LEARN --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHHHHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE: During the above, several QUICK CUTS or DISSOLVES should give the impression that they've worked through the night:) A)   Lead type being rapidly hand-set by Denton, helped by David -- a sub-headline forms: "House of Refuge, House of Shame." B)   Papers -- "THE NEWSIE NEWS" -- start rolling off the press as they examine it proudly. C)   They fold and bundle the papers, happy but exhausted D)   Pale pre-dawn light shines through the window framin Les as they pass him bundles of papers and he passes them out the window to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES. Race, Boots, Blink, Mush take the papers from Les and toss them into Kloppman's wagon -- he's on the driver's seat, keeping a lookout. Sarah climbs out the window, followed by the others. The last out is Jack -- carrying his belongings in a rolled bundle -- when he and the Newsies see each other, they freeze awkwardly. Silence until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thinkin' you'd like to take a shot at my schnozz -- right? (beat) Five to one says you can't break it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack laughs -- the tension breaks.    Hugs and backslaps as they climb onto the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops are looking for Jack -- we gotta protect him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any bull comes after jack, they gotta go through all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with the bundle, Jack -- ya leavin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sante Fe bound, Boots -- but not without givin' Pulitzer one last kiss goodbye --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points frantically at Weasel crossing the square towards them. They duck quickly -- and he weaves past whistling tunelessly, drunk. As Kloppman eases the wagon away, everybody looks back, shouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Weasel... Good ni-ight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around blearily:    must be the d.t.'s.

dialogues.speaker: 166B OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 185

dialogues.speaker: 185A HUNDREDS OF COPIES OF THE NEWSIE NEWS, (OPTICAL)
dialogues.text: swirl and cascade, FILLING the SCREEN as we see SUPERIMPOSED a series of living portraits of the working children of the 1890s... young boys in too- large caps and too-small coats, holding lunchpails... holding picks and shovels far too large for them... girls in shapeless dresses sewing, or scrubbing... shining eyes, dirty faces... sad expressions beginning to bloom into hope as they snatch and read the news that the headline proclaims as it whirls TOWARD us ON the

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: We see that same headline across --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he reads the Newsie News at breakfast attended by a butler (the Rough Rider) in a khaki uniform. He's reading a headline: "HOUSE OF REFUGE, HOUSE OF SHAME" with a subhead beneath it: "SCANDAL HIDDEN FROM TEDDY ON VISIT." We glimpse a famous walrus mustache as the Man slams his fist on the table in anger. A figure steps INTO FRAME across the table: Denton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd feel that way, Governor Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dis-graceful, Denty! Those poor boys -- and I did nothing! (pure steel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until now! The Rough Rider snaps out a silk hat and a silverheaded walking stick. Teddy snatches them as if they were armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Newsies look anxiously around the square, empty except for them. They take pains to conceal Jack among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when's the others comin', Cowboy? Jack looks glumly at the empty square; at the gates of the World where Weasel and his goons are beginning to line up, clubs in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't comin'... There ain't gonna be nobody but us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are silent, disappointed, feeling alone and defeated.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then Les steps forward, a defiant look on his face, glaring at the goons beyond the gates. He sings out loud and clear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of   Factory Boys                    RACETRACK appears in   the square;        NO! followed by   others. The       WHAT IF THE DELANCEYS COM boys begin   to take heart --   OUT SWINGING, WILL WE HEA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More kids are appearing;        SINGING, WHO CAN HEAR A L messengers, garment girls,      WHISTLE BLOW? kids of all kinds --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids are coming from everywhere, filling the   square -- Spot and the Brooklyn Newsies; more and more   kids, cheering, waving the Newsie News -- Jack and   David laug in triumph as shouting and MUSIC RISES UP TO   --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG RESONATES in the golden dome; Pulitzer stares down at the crowd as the mayor, sweating as usual, waves the Newsies' paper at him. Seitz sits reading a copy, impressed, as Jonathan fields phone calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all yelling at me -- me! -- factory owners, bankers, businessmen -- the whole city's at a standstill and they're blaming it on me -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not listening) Kelly's down there. He should be back in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the Newsie News) Those kids got out a pretty good paper, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too good! Those illiterate guttersnipes couldn't have done this on their own. Somebody's behind this, trying to pull a fast one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hearst on the line, sir. Wants to know if you've read the Newsies' paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulitzer glowers in suspicion at the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not taking the heat for this -- you've got to talk to them -- settle it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Hearst I'm busy! (ominously) I'll settle it all right -- once and for all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge doors of the World Building open and Seitz marches out, flanked by guards. The crowd opens a path as he marches up to Jack and David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, I don't transact business with no office boys.    We talk to old Joe hisself or we don't talk. Period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsies love it. Seitz stiffles a smile at Jack's bravado -- a smile of admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I guess you talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack beckons David to follow as they enter the huge doors and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: open as Seitz ushers them inside, closes the doors, leaving them alone. Pulitzer waits by the windows, a looming shadowy figure; sounds of CHANTING, SHOUTING floating up from below. David is awed by the palatial office, but Jack saunters coolly to the windows past --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to listen to me, boy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to, Joe -- (opens a window; crowd noise pours in) -- but I can't hear ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a deal -- you broke it. You're going back to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. But you can't put every kid in that square in jail. They ain't goin' away, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither am I. I can wait them out. It won't be me that's hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods at David who produces a paper, reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Since the strike, the World's circulation has dropped 70 per cent; advertising has been cut in half -- ' (stops reading) Every day you lose thousands of dollars -- just so you can beat us out of a lousy tenth of a cent per paper. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't about money, Dave -- if Joe gives in, that would mean nothin's like us got power. He can't let that happen -- no matter what it costs him. Right, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm about to show you what power really is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the window shut; CROWD NOISE abruptly DROPS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the police outside waiting to arrest you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lousy double-crossing -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- then I'll deal with that rabble in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's crossing to a buzzer on his desk; Jack, thinking fast, snatches up a copy of the Newsies News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya got me, Joe -- but tell me one thing, willya? How'd ya like our paper -- nice printin', ain't it? Right off the presses of one of New York's greatest newspapers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stops him.    He looks at Jack, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the papers have an agreement... we print nothing about the newsies. Whose press did you use? (as Jack shrugs, smiles) It was Hearst, wasn't it...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Hearst? Nah, it was yo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David quickly stops him, seeing the gleam in Pulitzer's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. Whoever helped you print this lying rag is trying to break the strike, get the jump on the rest of us. Well, you're going to expose this backstabber to the other owners -- in exchange, I'll call off the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and David exchange glances, seeing an opening --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not enough, Joe -- you gotta deal with our demands. Otherwise, our lips are sealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) All right, all right -- just say the traitor's name. It's Hearst, isn't it? Say it! Say the name of the scoundrel whose press you used so I can make him the disgrace of the newspaper world! Say his name, damn you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thunders over them, eyes blazing in triumph. The boys say nothing, just smile up at him knowingly until at last the horrible truth begins to dawn and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just wanna say, 'Thanks, Joe.' (as he stares, stunned) And Hearst and them other owners? Maybe they don't have to know. Depends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
